caption: 👌Pretty delicious but expensive pho in Chicago. Their beef was really hard to chew and the noodle was not fully boiled so it was hard to digest them. ($15 for the Pho) however, their broth was great that I might want to try one more. But, it’s still overpriced for the food. Way too much.
vietnamese food at this spot - very tasty. This location is absolutely outstanding. I had a cousin come into town and she asked me to go back here. The bill was fair I would say.

Ordered the Caramelized Shrimp Rice Bowl - Brown rice, shrimp, ginger, sesame seeds, carrots,pickled daikon carrots mix, cilantro, jalapenos, cucumbers for $13.00 - what I got is what you see, a bowl full of rice, about 4 paper thin slices of cucumber and jalapeno,  5-6 shrimp, a few shreds of pickled carrot and daikon.  For what I paid, I expected a LOT more, but I guess that's what is to be expected in the French Market :(
Great location for vietnamese food. Honestly my favorite evening place. Bring your hunger - portions are generous. Feels like a place in Los Angeles I liked.
Had the classic banh mi. First time having a cold banh mi. Not crazy about it. Would try another option.
The baos are great but the stir fry noodles is bad. Service is okay.
Missed with spring roll hit with great pho . Overall nice place to eat

Excellent food. If you don't normally eat vegan, you will NOT feel like you're missing anything. In fact, you'll be pleasantly surprised. Everything here is excellent and the staff are always great. Try a smoothie!
Delicious menu items. Always love stopping here on my way through the Loop.

Delicious pork belly baos, Vietnamese wagyu baos, and tender Curry chicken. I haven't tried anything else from here but the baos are generously filled and flavorful, the bao bun is fluffy and sweet. 3 baos for $10.75 is a good price for what you get. They're filling. Plus you can get a caramelized egg on the side for a dollar. It's not very caramelized, but it's good. It is basically like a tea egg which is a hard-boiled egg steeped in flavorings for days. Saigon sister's egg doesn't seem steeped long enough unfortunately. But it's still a very good effort and worth the dollar. I'm surprised this place doesn't have higher ratings. I love it and will keep going back.

Ordered the shrimp spring rolls and the beef pho. The spring rolls were OK. The broth in the pho was pretty good but the beef in it looked a little scary. I ended up picking it all out because it made me uneasy to look at it- but I’m sure it was ok to eat. Overall, It’s a bit pricey here for quality of food.
Poor quality pho

Was visiting from Ca. & was soooooo excited to try something new @ the FRENCH market !!! Well there are no words to even begin to describe what an EPIC fail this was i every level , tasted like something from A box bought from a 1$ store , i took one bite & headed back to the stand for a refund which they weren’t too happy about & treated me horrifically !! Lost my appetite to attempt to try another stand @ that point !!! SML portions , no Flavor !!! All around negative experience !! You’ve been warned !!

Amazing place! .. I have been craving Pho for the longest time and this place hit the spot. I was confused with all the selection and ordered a sandwich instead. As soon as I received my order the lady realized it wasn't what I thought. I was going to keep it but she insisted to switch it to the soup. I've never been so amazed with the great customer service after it all i find out she's the owner! I just want to say I'm super happy with my pho soup and the customer service so worth it!!
I've had several occasions where Saigon barely fills the bowls of pho past the halfway point.
In a french market. Have to pick up food and eat in a food court. Bowls are smaller than typical Vietnamese restaurants.
Good Vietnamese sandwiches. Can't go wrong with this place!
Great place to go. It is quick and not overpriced. Both the salad and sandwich I tried were bursting with flavor.

The stir fry noodles dish with pork belly was very fatty, greasy and not much veggie.  Nothing special where you couldn't get a stir fry dish elsewhere.  Their menu does have quite a selection.  May give their sandwiches a try next time.
Great quick lunch option. Curry and carmelized chicken noodles are my go-to (add an egg!).

I never feel the need to negatively review a business for it's food or service. Sadly, the only "Vietnamese" aspect of this restaurant is the word 'Saigon' in the name. The bowl of Pho was stale and had no taste of cultural authenticity. The baguette was overpriced and as Americanized as the cashier lady who can't even speak a word of Vietnamese. The coffee comes in a can and tasted like water saturated with milk and sugar. The stall is located in a quaint little French plaza, redeeming itself with an additional star for atmospheric depiction of Vietnamese colonial history.
On Saturdays they offer up three different types of bao as a special. The pork belly bao is insanely good.  The chicken and wagu versions were tasty as well. Nice treat.
(Translated by Google) VBQ  (Original) VBQ

I have tried all the sandwiches on the menu and love every single one. It is slightly more expensive than the Vietnamese Banh Mi shops on the north side, but this one is downtown, and their ingredients are more savory, such as the VBQ. Also, I get a corporate discount so I think the trek down here is worth every last penny.

Delicious and modern banh mi conveniently located in the trendy French Market. The line can get long but they turn around the orders very quickly so don't be discouraged. My favorites are the VBQ (Vietnamese BBQ) and meatball sandwiches. The rice bowls and spring rolls are also tasty but the shinning star is the sandwich selection.

I had been wanting to try a banh mi sandwich for quite some time. Over the last 2 years I had a chance to try out 6 different spots and found that Saigon Sisters was right by where I work.  I've loved all of them but having some of the best sandwiches with spice almost across the street from where I work? How could you go wrong?  You can't. I guess if there is any going wrong is that I've spent far too much money here over the last year and will continue to do so as each bite is full of flavor that just never gets old with a huge variety of sandwiches to choose from in case you ever did get sick of one! (Which I don't see how you could..)

There are a lot of places for banh mi nowadays, but Saigon Sisters is among the better ones. There is quite a variety of sandwiches available, and my family and I have enjoyed all the ones we have sampled. The numerous condiments available allow you to tweak them to your taste. The location in the French Market makes it a good place for a quick lunch.

Any place that makes its own brand of sriracha is Excellent.  My first encounter with Saigon Sisters was when their T-Racha sauce debuted. That time and every other time, the people have been great. The food is nice and worth a stop if you're in that part of downtown.
Porky sandwiches... SO GOOD

This place is fantastic, both for lunch and dinner. The lunch consisted of the Vietnamese stand by's of Bahn Mi and Pho; both of which are excellent. Owner Dan is personable and friendly. However, the Pho would significantly benefit from more meat than as currently served. Dinner is approachable, unique and very, very delicious.
